items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding from the evening of 2nd February 2026. No further rainfall is forecast, but river levels remain high. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Refer to Local Authority website for road closures. This message will be updated by 01:00PM on 3 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Cam and River Wriggle, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels today and overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 02 and 03 February 2026. This information is correct as of 3:00pm on Monday 02 February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 15cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has areas with some water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Tuesday 03 February 2026.

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 17:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect riverside properties on Forewood Lane and near Crowhurst Recreation Ground. From 22:00 03/02/2026 Bexhill Road Recreation ground, and gardens that back onto the rec (or near the Combe Haven) could be affected. Rain should stop Tuesday evening. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Crowhurst by 06:00 04/02/2026, but river levels will remain higher than normal most of the week in Bulverhythe. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Install flood protection products in Crowhurst. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to rise in response to the forecasted rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.57m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.51m and stable. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.

Pumping operations will start at Westover and Huish Episcopi stations once river levels allow. We will use the Parrett Relief Channel when river levels and water levels on the moors allows.

Monday is forecast to be mainly dry. A period of more sustained rain is forecast to last all day on Tuesday and rivers are likely to respond to this. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Flooding is possible on 03/02/2026 as up to 30mm more rainfall is forecast on Tuesday. Flooding could affect land, fields, and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around and affect the mill building at East Wellow. Property flooding is possible. A Flood Warning will be issued if we expect properties to flood. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 12:00 04/02/2026. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have, including pumps. This message will be updated by 20:00 03/02/2026.

items.message:

If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 13:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect Hammer Lane, Grove Hill, and Mill Lane Hellingly. From 16:00 03/02/2026 flooding could affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 22:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect North Street, River Lane, The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Rain should stop by Tuesday evening. items.description: Western Rother
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding.

Minor flooding is already affecting gardens, roads, and fields at Lodsbridge near Selham, and Fittleworth Mill. Rain is forecast for much of Tuesday. River levels along the Western Rother could rise higher than the last couple of days. From 11:00 03/02/2026, minor flooding could affect Mill Lane and Old Mill Lane, Sheet, Iping Lane, Stedham Lane, and The Wharf, Midhurst. From 14:00 03/02/2026 flooding could approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham, and Fittleworth Mill. River levels should begin to reduce in Liss by 06:00 04/02/2026, but not until Thursday near Fittleworth. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Avoid roads that flood (Iping) 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
Minor flooding is currently affecting fields, roads, and gardens. If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 16:00 03/02/2026 flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. Rain should stop Tuesday evening. River levels likely to peak similar to recent days. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 15:00 04/02/2026, but could stay high most of the week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
Minor flooding is currently affecting fields, roads, and gardens. If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 15:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect gardens of Bridge Cottage on the B2028, gardens of properties on Sloop Lane, roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. From 20:00 03/02/2026 flooding could affect the Anchor Inn, gardens at Barcombe Mills, and Barcombe Mills road. Rain will stop Tuesday evening. Only showers are forecast Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 09:00 04/02/2026 near Ardingly, 20:00 04/02/2026 in Barcombe. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , and operating structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to reduce flood risk. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood, including Barcombe Mills Road. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 02 February 2026 . 
River levels are high on parts of the River Thames and its tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 02 Feb 2026, especially in the Eynsham area. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to rise until tomorrow morning, 03 Feb 2026. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: This is a flood alert update. High river levels and further rain this evening and over the next few days may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Check local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 3 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
The river level in the Washford River at Beggearn Huish remains high on Monday 2nd February but is currently falling. Flooding is possible as a result. Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and their tributaries, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. 
Monday is forecast to be mainly dry, with a band of more sustained rain all day Tuesday and rivers are likely to respond.
We continue to monitor the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are falling today Monday 2nd February but are expected to rise on Tuesday 3rd February due to sustained rain forecasted. Low lying land and roads are expected to be most affected, particularly areas and roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Monday is expected to be dry, however there is a band of more sustained rain is forecasted all day Tuesday. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1PM on 03/02/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides combined with high river flows from upstream overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 2:15 AM to 4:15 AM on 03/02/2026 
The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65 mAOD at 3:15 AM on 03/02/2026.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. Flooding of properties is not expected.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 255 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain steady for the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message:
High tides on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:15 on 03/02/2026. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.33 m. Total forecast tide is 6.07 metres Chart Datum (3.02 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Light North Easterly Force 4 wind. Small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Wednesday's tide at 00:30 04/02/2026 is forecast to be the same height (3.02 mAOD). Flood risk should reduce from Friday afternoon. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . We routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Access could be restricted. Take care if visiting Climping beach. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include Swanage Bay, and Portland Harbour. In Swanage there may be a risk to the lower end of High Street road by the Pier Head so avoid parking vehicles in this area due to wave overtopping and flying debris. The tidal forecast is for a peak level at Bournemouth. The first Forecast high water of 2.51mAODN at 9.30pm 02 February, with 2.30m waves, with Easterly force 6 winds. The second forecast high water is at 09.45am with a level of 2.75mAODN with Easterly force 5 winds. A peak level at Portland of 1.85mAODN at 07.45am 03 February with 1.7m waves, Easterly Force 5 winds. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

The high tide at Plymouth on Tuesday is at 06:43, times of high water will vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 3.03mAOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.4 and 0.53 metres above tide table level. Force 4 to 6 South Easterly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.8m are forecast over the high tide. 

Coastal conditions should ease by Thursday PM. 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides and strong winds over the next four days may lead to flooding.   

Flooding is possible from the evening of Monday 2 February over all high tides to Friday 6 February inclusive.   

Areas particularly at risk include Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park at Fowey, Quay Street and Recreation ground at Lostwithiel, Polperro Harbour, Quay Road and The Quay at Looe and the B3247 at Seaton. High tides at Plymouth on Monday are 18:29, times of high water vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.73m. Expect tide levels to be  0.54 metres above tide table level with waves up to 3m. Force 7 E winds are forecast. Further flood alerts and warnings are likely, with tides peaking on Tuesday and Wednesday.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Monday 02/02 to Thursday 05/02.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.67m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.65m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and additional pumps are operational at Northmoor and Saltmoor. Monday is forecast to be mainly dry, with a band of more sustained rain all day Tuesday and rivers are likely to respond.
We continue to monitor the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Riverside Park
items.message: High river levels are expected to cause flooding until at least Wednesday. Flooding is expected on 02/02/2026 due to a combination of high river flows and tide levels. High tide at Southampton is forecast at 23:30 2/2/26 and 02:00 03/02/2026. The water level is expected to be 4.84 metres Chart Datum (2.10 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high at Gaters Mill. Tuesday morning's tide at 11:45 03/02/2026 will be 20cm higher. Flooding impacts will more extensive. More rain is forecast; this means that flows in the River Itchen will stay high. A Flood Warning will remain in place while there is a risk of property flooding. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Southampton City Council have opened the sea door at Woodmill. Activate any flood protection products you may have. Including defences around the White Swan pub. This message will be updated by 03/02/2026 18:00.

items.message:
High tides and strong winds over the next three days may lead to flooding.   

Flooding is possible from the evening of Monday 2 February over all high tides to the morning of Thursday 5 February inclusive.   

Areas particularly at risk include Mousehole, Newlyn, Penzance, Longrock, Marazion, Praa Sands and Porthleven harbour. High tides at Newlyn on Monday is at 17:15, times of high water vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is 2.95m. Expect tide levels to be 0.59 metres above tide table level with waves up to 3.1m. Force 7 E winds are forecast. Further flood alerts and warnings are likely, with tides peaking on Tuesday and Wednesday.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and considering whether the closure of Toll Bridge Road will be required. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst.

River levels are high on parts of the River Thames from Mapledurham to Sonning. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 02 Feb 2026, especially in the Sonning area. Further rainfall is expected today and tomorrow. River levels are falling and we expect this to continue, but they remain responsive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 03 Feb 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 from 11:00 as a lot of rain is forecast Tuesday (20mm). 
Minor flooding could affect Barnham Road and Lake Lane. Flooding could affect fields, the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road, land at Riverside Caravan Centre, and small parts of land off Durban Road. Minor impacts may also affect Arun Business Park, Shripney Trade Park, Whitfield Close, Maryland Crescent, Rife Way, Links Avenue and Kingsmead. Rain will stop Tuesday evening. Only isolated showers Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Barnham by 06:00 04/02/2026, but not until 16:00 04/02/2026 in Bersted, where the river will be high all week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation clearing debris screens through Barnham. Our pumps at Felpham are running. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Including in Barnham. Avoid roads that flood (Barnham Rd and Lake Lane). 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 . as another 20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
River levels are already higher than normal following Sunday's rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields and rural roads. From 11:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect gardens of isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. From 14:00 03/02/2026, flooding could affect gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. River levels will probably be similar to events of the past week. Rain is forecast to stop Tuesday evening. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 20:00 04/02/2026. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langney Haven
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 23:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect gardens of properties of Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park will also be affected. Rain will stop Tuesday evening. River levels could rise to a similar height as on 27/01/2026. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 16:00 04/02/2026, but could remain higher than normal all week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures at Fence Bridge and Crumbles to reduce flood risk. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Install flood protection products in Langney Green. 
This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
From 13:00 03/02/2026 minor flooding could affect fields, roads, and gardens of isolated properties between Coolham and Henfield. It is possible water may approach gardens of Church Close, Shipley. Rain should stop Tuesday evening. River levels could peak at a similar height to recent days. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 10:00 04/02/2026. Only isolated showers are forecast Wednesday and Thursday, so river levels should return nearer to normal by Thursday. Although more unsettled weather at the end of the week could increase flood risk again. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood, including Slaughter Bridge, Coolham Road.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message: This is a flood alert update. River levels are steady but remaining high due to continued rainfall and high groundwater levels. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood. Further rain is expected today and over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Check local authority websites for road closures. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 3 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Carisbrooke and Hunny Hill on the Lukely Brook
items.message: The Lukely Brook is higher than normal, but has now fallen after Sunday's rain. No rain is forecast Monday (02/02/2026). River levels will continue to slowly fall. However, on Tuesday (03/02/2026), another 30mm of rain is forecast to affect Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. If this falls on the Lukely Brook, from 09:00 03/02/2026, flooding could affect property at the bottom of Castle Street. The Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road will also flood. Water levels will be very high at Caesars Road and Old Westminster Lane, and the river could come out of bank flooding roads and parked cars. We are closely monitoring the weather forecast and river levels. Activate any flood protection products you may have. This message will be updated by 14:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: St Johns, Ryde
items.message: The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St Johns Station has now returned near to normal following Sunday's heavy rainfall. Only isolated showers are forecast for Monday (02/02/2026), the river should fall a little further. On Tuesday (03/02/2026), another 30mm of rain is expected to affect Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. If this occurs on the Monktonmead Brook, from 09:00 03/02/2026, flooding could affect depot, tracks, and station buildings at St John's Station. Water on the tracks could be up to 0.5m deep. We are closely monitoring the situation and keeping the Monktonmead Brook clear of blockages. Activate any flood protection products you may have. Move vehicles from low lying land next to the river. A Flood Warning will remain in force for this area while the risk of property flooding continues. This message will be updated by 16:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: River Medina
items.message: The River Medina is higher than normal, but is now falling following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, roads, and gardens at Blackwater, and near Sandy Lane. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday. The river should slowly fall a little further. However, another 20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. From 09:00 03/02/2026 property flooding could again be possible. Potentially affecting Blackwater Mill buildings, property at Sandy Lane, Blackwater Hollow, Blackwater. Property on the riverbank at St George's Way may also flood. Flooding will also affect near Mill Farm, and fields, roads, and gardens. We are checking rivers for blockages. Activate any flood protection products you may have. A Flood Warning will remain in force for this area while the risk of property flooding continues. This message will be updated by 14:00 03/02/2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: River levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. River levels are falling at Budbridge and Alverstone, levels are falling slowly at Sandown. Flooding will continue to affect a small number of properties at Alverstone and Langbridge, restrict access to Horringford, and affect footpaths. Garden flooding is expected to be continuing at Whitwell High Street. Flooding will also continue to affect Moreton Common and Golf Links roads. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown Sewage works are also continuing to flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts are also expected to be continuing at Nicholas Close Brading. On Tuesday (03/02/2026), another 30mm is forecast. River levels and flood risk will remain high for the next few days. We are operating Bembridge sluices. Ensure any flood protection products you may have remain in place. Flood Warnings are in force for the Eastern Yar. This message will be updated by 20:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: River Hamble
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more rain is forecast (up to 30mm). 
The river level is still falling after heavy rain yesterday (01/02/2026). There is potential for further heavy rain tomorrow (03/02/2026). Any further rain will lead to flooding at Durley School, areas around Durley Mill and Botley, where surface water flooding from the main road is possible. Botley Mill could be affected. No property flooding is currently expected from the river at Bishops Waltham. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 12:00 04/02/2026. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have In Bishops Waltham, please check the details of the village flood plan. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have fallen following the rainfall overnight. River levels will increase at each high tide, as the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing out to sea. Tide times are 02/02/2026 23:48 and 03/02/2026 11:54. On Tuesday, up to 30mm of rainfall is forecast, this may lead to flooding. If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could affect gardens or properties nearest to the river in Marsh Road. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by Thursday. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, including Marsh Road, Gurnard. This message will be updated by 13:00 03/02/2026.

However, further rain tomorrow, Tuesday 3 February, means levels could increase again from Tuesday afternoon. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: Middle River Roding
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. River levels are now falling steadily. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message: Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected from 2  February 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving. We are closely monitoring the situation . If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Fittleworth on the Western River Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high and rising at Fittleworth, following Sunday's rain. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday. However, flood water will continue to get a little closer to Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties through Monday. Water will continue to affect fields, gardens, and rural roads. Rain is forecast for much of Tuesday. There remains uncertainty in amounts and location of rainfall. However, it is probable that property flooding will occur in Fittleworth on Tuesday. River levels may not begin to fall in Fittleworth until Thursday, and will likely remain higher than normal all week. Keep in place any flood protection products you may have in Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 18:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: Pulborough on the River Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high, but currently falling in Pulborough. It is possible that river levels in Pulborough could rise a little Monday afternoon, in response to Sunday's rainfall. However it is thought river levels will not initially rise far. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads, and gardens will continue to affect the A29, gardens of properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Rain is forecast for much of Tuesday. There remains uncertainty in amounts and location of rainfall. However, it is probable that river levels will rise Tuesday and Wednesday, and property flooding could be possible. River levels may not begin to fall in Pulborough until Friday, and will likely remain higher than normal all week. We are closely monitoring the situation and our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Pulborough. This message will be updated by 19:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels in the Salisbury Plain have risen in response to recent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Levels are forecast to continue to rise throughout the week. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hayling Island
items.message: High tides on Tuesday may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:08 on 03/02/2026. The weather increases tide table values by 0.4 m. The total forecast tide is 5.19 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light North Easterly Force 3 wind. The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke corner, near the nature reserve, and at Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach may also be affected. Wednesday's tide at 00:44 04/02/2026 is forecast to be 12 cm lower (2.34 mAOD). We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Avoid South Hayling seafront. Shingle can be thrown by wind and waves. This message will be updated by 15:00 03/02/2026.

items.message: The River Medina is higher than normal, but is now falling following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, roads, and gardens at Blackwater, and near Sandy Lane. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday. The river should slowly fall a little further. However, another 20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. From 09:00 03/02/2026 property flooding could again be possible. Potentially affecting Blackwater Mill buildings, property at Sandy Lane, Blackwater Hollow, Blackwater. Property on the riverbank at St George's Way may also flood. Flooding will also affect near Mill Farm, and fields, roads, and gardens. We are checking rivers for blockages. Activate any flood protection products you may have. This message will be updated by 14:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides over the next two days may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 1:45PM to 5:45PM on 02/02/2026 and 2:15AM to 6:15AM on 03/02/2026. 
Locations most affected will be the Port of Sunderland and coastal roads and footpaths. Further flooding is possible on all high tides until 05/02/2026. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid coastal footpaths, which may be flooded and beware of large waves. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding over the next three days. 
Flooding is expected on 02 February 2026 , due to a combination of high river flows and tide levels.   
High tide at Southampton is forecast at 23:30 02/02/2026 and 02:00 03/02/2026. The water level is expected to be 4.84 metres Chart Datum (2.10 mAOD). Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Riverside Park will also be flooded. Levels may also be very high at Gaters Mill. Tuesday morning's tide at 11:45 03/02/2026 will be 20cm higher. Flooding impacts will be more extensive. More rain is forecast and so flows in the River Itchen will stay high. Please remain prepared. 
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities . Southampton City Council are operating the sea door at Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . Including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Meon
items.message:
High river levels on Monday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 02 February 2026 as a lot of rain fell overnight. 
River levels in the River Meon at Titchfield remain high, although falling slowly. Flooding will continue to affect Titchfield Hill with very high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and Tanneries Industrial Estate. Water could be continuing to flow across the main road and cause flooding to the front of Bridge Cottage. The remainder of today is forecast to be dry. On Tuesday, 03/02/2026, up to 30mm of rainfall is forecast. If as much rain falls as forecast, river levels will rise. River levels will remain high for the next few days. A Flood Warning is in force for Titchfield. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have particularly properties close to the river in Titchfield. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour Side
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding tomorrow morning.  
Flooding is expected from 8.15am to 12.15pm Tuesday 3 February.  
Areas most at risk include areas in close proximity to Christchurch Harbour including Mudeford, Stanpit, the Quomps and Wick area. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Christchurch. The forecast high water is at 10.15am Tuesday 3 February, with a level of 1.64 mAODN with Easterly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)  
We are closing flood gates and closely monitoring the situation.  
Activate any flood protection products you may have and avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for today, Monday 2 February 2026. The Great Stour remains high today following the weekend’s rainfall. There remains an ongoing possibility of flooding to low lying land, paths or roads alongside the Great Stour including in Canterbury City Centre. Levels have temporarily peaked in all locations between Wye and Fordwich. However, further rain tomorrow, Tuesday 3 February, means some flooding could be experienced from Tuesday night onwards. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 3 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels remain high following recent rainfall. Flooding is possible on 2nd February 2026. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 1pm on 3rd February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 05/02/2026 because of a wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect cellars of properties at the Southern end of the village at South End Close and the Dolphin pub. Further rain (up to 30mm) is forecast tomorrow. Groundwater levels in Hursley are expected to rise into next week. From Saturday 07/02/2026, if levels rise at their current rate, it is possible that much of the village will experience cellar flooding impacts as well as sewerage system impacts. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 09 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Till
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 28 January 2026 
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain are rising. Areas that could be affected include: Tilshead, Orcheston, Shrewton and Berwick St James. The groundwater level at the Tilshead MOD borehole has risen to 109.14m, and is expected to rise into next week. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 12:00AM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bridge Road, Emsworth
items.message:
Forecast rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more rain is forecast (up to 30mm). 
The river level has fallen following rainfall yesterday afternoon. No impacts are expected today (02/02/2026). Tomorrow (03/02/2026), river levels could come out of bank, flooding the road and riverside car park. We may issue a Flood Warning tomorrow evening (03/02/3036) for the onset of property flooding from the river. River levels might not fall until 06:00 04/02/2026. 
We are checking rivers for blockages at Bridge Road, and managing the level in Emsworth Mill Pond. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently high at our Draycot borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to rise over the coming days and levels to remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12pm 3 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Simeon Street Rec Ground, Ryde
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more rain is forecast (up to 30mm). 
Flooding could affect Marymead Close and the Simeon Street recreation ground. Rain is forecast to continue until Wednesday 04/02/2026. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 06:00 04/02/2026. With the current forecast we do not expect property to flood, but we will issue further advice if the flood risk increases. If required, we will re-deploy the drop boards at Simeon Street Recreation ground. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and the recreation ground which may be needed as a flood storage area. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on Tuesday 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding over the next three days.  
Flooding is expected on the mornings of Tuesday 3, Wednesday 4 and Thursday 5 February 2026.  
Areas particularly at risk include exposed coastal areas of Plymouth Sound including Cawsand, Kingsand and The Hoe, Millbrook, and low lying areas on the Tidal Lynher, Tamar, Tavy, Plym and Yealm estuaries. High tides of concern at Plymouth are Tuesday 06:45, Wednesday 07:30 and Thursday 08:00 times of high water vary along the coast. Forecast total high tide level is set to peak at 3.03mAOD on Tuesday. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.48 and 0.56 metres above tide table level. Strong force 4-5 SE winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m are forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation .  
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and activate any flood protection products you may have.  
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected for 2 hours either side of Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:08 on 03/02/2026.   
The weather increases tide table values by 0.4 m. The total forecast tide is 5.19 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light North Easterly Force 3 wind. The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke corner, near the nature reserve, and at Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach may also be affected. Wednesday's tide at 00:44 04/02/2026 is forecast to be 12 cm lower (2.34 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Parrett, River Cary

items.message: River levels in the upper catchments have now fallen but considerable water remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett and River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway. Monday 2nd February is expected to be dry, however there is a band of sustained rain forecasted all day Tuesday 3rd February. River levels are expected to rise in response to the forecasted rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

We continue to closely monitor the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.description: Upper Meon
items.message:
High river levels on Monday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 02 February 2026 following the overnight rainfall. 
River levels remain high following rain overnight. Levels at East Meon and West Meon are falling, levels at Wickham are stable. At Wickham, the river is likely to be continuing to flood gardens, Millennium Water Meadows, commercial and industrial property downstream of A334, and property access in Bridge Street. On Tuesday, 03/02/2026, up to 30mm of rainfall is forecast. If as much rain falls as forecast, river levels will rise. Flooding will affect roads through East Meon, West Meon, Exton and Meonstoke, and there will be further impacts at Wickham. A Flood Warning is in force for Wickham. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have particularly properties close to the river, or with pumps for groundwater. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: East Meon to Mislingford on the River Meon
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. On Monday. However, on Tuesday more widespread rain is forecast and property flooding could again be possible. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.  
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Please remain prepared. This Flood Warning may be re-issued on Tuesday.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message: This is a Groundwater Flood Warning Update. Groundwater levels at Iwerne Hill Farm and Dickley Down boreholes continue to be steady but high. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should continue to keep any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers deployed.  Further showers are forecast throughout the weekend with heavier rain expected from Monday.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk. Please take care and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 4 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: A361 East Lyng to Burrowbridge
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.67m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.65m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 remains closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. The River Tone level is still too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping here once river levels allow. 
Monday is forecast to be mainly dry, with a band of more sustained rain all day Tuesday and rivers are likely to respond. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking floodbanks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving.  We are closely monitoring the situation .  If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts .  This message will be updated by 11:15AM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (lower) at Langport Westover Trading Estate
items.message:
The level in the Westover Drain remains high but stable. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying land and roads near the River Parrett at Langport. Areas most at risk include Cheapside, Whatley Mews, Parrett Close, Bow Street, Moor Park and Westover Trading Estate. 

Pumping operations will start at Westover and Huish Episcopi stations once river levels allow. We will use the Parrett Relief Channel when river levels and water levels on the moors allows.

Monday 2nd February is expected to be dry, however there is a band of sustained rain forecasted all day Tuesday 3rd February. 

We continue to monitor the situation closely and our Field Teams have been clearing debris screens and checking flood banks and spillways. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354
items.message:
Flood warning in force: Groundwater flooding for the North Winterborne, north of the A354 
Flooding is expected for: Groundwater flooding for Turnworth, Winterborne Stickland, Winterborne Houghton, Clenston, Whatcombe and Whitechurch. High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected from 2 February 2026 onwards. 
The groundwater level at the Delcombe Wood borehole has risen to 144.05m above sea level, levels are forecast to peak early this week, though further rainfall may cause levels to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. Roads may be impassable due to flood water, do not drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:30AM on 9 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain has fallen this week (41mm). 
Flooding is affecting the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will be flowing across Rectory Lane and behind the Buck's Head Pub. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley in the coming days then groundwater levels at the borehole in Meonstoke will rise into next week. If not, then levels may peak over the weekend. Flooding at the Bucks Head Pub could occur in the next two weeks with further heavy rain. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible , as a lot of rain fell this week (41mm). 
From Friday 30/01/2026, flooding will affect cellars of a small number of properties in Lower West Street. From Monday 02/02/2026, an increased number of properties on West Street are expected to be affected by cellar flooding. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. Groundwater levels at the borehole at Whitedale Farm are expected to continue rising through next week and it is possible that properties on East Street could be affected by cellar flooding during this time. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Ems
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 , as another 10-20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. 
If as much rain falls on Tuesday as predicted, from 10:00 03/02/2026, minor flooding could affect fields, Brook Meadows, rural roads, and gardens of properties on North Street, River Street and at the Wren Centre, Westbourne. Also near Lumley Mill and Victoria Terrace, Emsworth. River levels may peak a little higher than on Sunday. Rain is forecast to stop Tuesday evening. Only isolated showers are predicted Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by the early hours of Wednesday, but will remain higher than normal all week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , operating our structure at Constant Springs, and clearing debris screens. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Including in Westbourne and Emsworth, flooding may occur quickly. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Gurnard on the Gurnard Luck
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. On Monday. However, on Tuesday more widespread rain is forecast and property flooding could again be possible. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Please remain prepared. This Flood Warning may be re-issued on Tuesday.

items.description: Wickham on the River Meon
items.message: The River Meon is high, but is now falling following Sunday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect the Millennium Meadows, and commercial and industrial property downstream of the main A334 Fareham Road. The high river could also affect access to property in Bridge Street. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday. The river should slowly fall a little further. However, another 20mm of rain is forecast Tuesday. Property flooding in Wickham could again be possible from 10:00 03/02/2026. We are checking rivers for blockages. Activate any flood protection products you may have. This message will be updated by 15:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: River Wallington
items.message:
High river levels tomorrow evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more heavy rain is forecast (30mm). 
If this forecast rain affects the River Wallington, flooding could affect Boarhunt Mill, surrounding the Mill building. River levels may also come close to the top of the defence wall in the centre of Wallington village and surface water could affect Broadcut Retail Park. Water Levels near the Cob and Pen pub will rise at high tide (00:30 04/02/2026). This could be a similar event to 01/02/2026. A Flood Warning will be issued if we expect properties to flood. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 16:00 04/02/2026. 
We are checking flood defences including the defence wall in Wallington village. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Please keep away from the river until water levels begin to fall. 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.57m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.51m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road about 8.8m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. 

Pumping operations will start at Westover and Huish Episcopi stations once river levels allow. We will also use the Parrett Relief Channel when river levels and water levels on the moors allows.

Monday is forecast to be mainly dry. A band of more sustained rain is forecast to last all day Tuesday and rivers are likely to respond to this. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. 

This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message: Water levels remain high and continued flooding is expected during Monday and Tuesday. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. Levels in the River Tone and on Currymoor are stable although still very high. The River Tone is still too high for pumping at Currymoor station. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Monday is forecast to be mainly dry, but a band of sustained rain is forecast all day Tuesday. River levels are expected to rise in response to the rainfall. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1pm on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Denton
items.message: Groundwater is high, but currently falling at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to remain high. Springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise again, and a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Houndean Bottom borehole should pause around 06/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. Flood impacts may remain until mid February. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, and small amounts of water could flow down roads. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster. Potentially affecting a small number of cellars in Stoughton and Walderton from 04/02/2026. With more water flowing along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Very little rain is forecast mid week. Groundwater rise at Compton borehole should pause around 07/02/2026. However, with the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high and slowly rising. Light rain is forecast for much of Sunday. Even at such short lead times there is uncertainty in amounts. 20mm of rain could be recorded Sunday. Another 10-15mm of rain is forecast for Tuesday. Groundwater is expected to continue rising. Springs will appear, water will be in fields, small amounts of water will flow down roads, groundwater will affect the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean, and may start to appear in a small number of basements. If we get the maximum rain Sunday and Tuesday, then groundwater could rise higher and faster, causing more water to flow on roads. Groundwater rise at Chilgrove borehole should pause around 07/02/2026, but will continue at East Dean borehole until at least the middle of February. With the weather outlook remaining unsettled, and more rain predicted on Friday, further groundwater rise is possible next weekend. Take care on roads that flood (Chilgrove, West Dean, Singleton, East Dean). Ensure pumps work. We will update this message by 18:00 06/02/2026.

items.message:

Flooding is possible from Monday 02/02/2026 because of a very wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Finchdean has risen by 67cm. It is possible that pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required from Monday 02/02/2026. During heavier rainfall events, surface water could affect property. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. Groundwater levels will rise into next week. If heavy rain affects the valley in the coming days, then it is possible that roads and more properties could be affected later in the week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with the Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 01/02/2026 due to a wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Kings Somborne has risen by 14cm. Flooding could affect cellars in a small number of properties along Winchester Road, in central King's Somborne and in Little Somborne from Sunday 01/02/2026. However, the groundwater level may peak before these impacts occur. Small amounts of rain are forecast from today (30/01/2026) to Monday (02/02/2026). If heavy rain affects Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, groundwater levels will continue rising well into next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hermitage Stream
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more rain is forecast (up to 30mm). 
This is a similar amount of rain to Sunday (01/02/2026) and similar areas will be at risk. Flooding could affect roads at Riders Lane and Purbrook Way as rising water levels in the Hermitage Stream restricts the Riders Lane Stream from draining into it effectively. At New Road, the river may come close close to bankfull, with very deep, fast flowing water in the channel. River levels will remain low today, but will rise with an increased flood risk tomorrow. Rainfall and flood risk will continue until the early hours of Wednesday morning (04/02/2026). 
We are clearing blockages from debris screens in Havant. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Monktonmead Brook at St Johns
items.message: The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St Johns Station has now returned near to normal following Sunday's heavy rainfall. Only isolated showers are forecast for Monday (02/02/2026), the river should fall a little further. On Tuesday (03/02/2026), another 30mm of rain is expected to affect Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. If this occurs on the Monktonmead Brook, from 09:00 03/02/2026, flooding could affect depot, tracks, and station buildings at St John's Station. Water on the tracks could be up to 0.5m deep. We are closely monitoring the situation and keeping the Monktonmead Brook clear of blockages. Activate any flood protection products you may have. Move vehicles from low lying land next to the river. This message will be updated by 15:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: Mead End Stream, Denmead
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 as more rain is forecast (up to 30mm). 
The river level is still returning to normal following 30mm of rain yesterday (01/02/2026). Another 30mm of rainfall is forecast for tomorrow (03/02/2026), this would lead to similar impacts. Flooding could affect roads and gardens at Forest Road, Creech View, The Liberty, Homemead and Anmore Road, Denmead. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 09:00 04/02/2026. 
We are clearing blockages from debris screens through Denmead. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 04 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wallington
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. On Monday. However, on Tuesday more widespread rain is forecast and property flooding could again be possible. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Please remain prepared. This Flood Warning may be re-issued on Tuesday.

items.description: Titchfield on the River Meon
items.message: River levels in the River Meon at Titchfield remain high, although falling slowly. Flooding will continue to affect Titchfield Hill with very high water levels at Titchfield Mill, Bridge Cottage and at the Tanneries Industrial Estate. Water could be continuing to flow across the main road and cause flooding to the front of Bridge Cottage. The remainder of today is forecast to be dry. On Tuesday, 03/02/2026, up to 30mm of rainfall is forecast. If as much rain falls as forecast, river levels will rise in response to the rainfall during Tuesday. River levels will remain high for the next few days. Ensure any flood protection products you may have are in place. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers‚ sewage and chemicals. This message will be updated by 16:00 03/02/2026.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Monday. 
Flooding is expected on 02 February 2026 from 10:30, as a lot of rain (40mm) fell on Sunday. 
Flooding will affect Moreton Common and Golf Links roads. Fort Holiday Park and Sandown Sewage works could flood as ditches struggle to drain to the main river. Impacts are also expected at Nicholas Close, Brading. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday. River levels in Sandown should begin to fall Monday afternoon. However, on Tuesday (03/02/2026), another 30mm is forecast. River levels and flood risk will remain high Monday through to Wednesday, potentially for the rest of the week. 
We are checking rivers for blockages , and operating Bembridge sluices. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lavant
items.message:
High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 03 February 2026 from 14:00 as a lot of rain is forecast Tuesday (20mm). 
Flooding could affect fields, roads and gardens. In East Lavant water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river. Water could also approach gardens of properties at The Sadlers in Westhampnett. Rain is forecast to stop Tuesday evening, with only isolated showers Wednesday and Thursday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in East Lavant by 10:00 04/02/2026. However, river levels will remain high throughout February and vulnerable to future rainfall events. More rain could be possible at the end of the week, which might cause more minor flooding. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and operating structures in Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk Avoid roads that flood (Sheepwash Lane). Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastoke
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected for 2 hours either side of Tuesday afternoon's tide at 12:08 on 03/02/2026.   
The weather increases tide table values by 0.4 m. The total forecast tide is 5.19 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Light North Easterly Force 3 wind. The shingle beach at Eastoke Corner has been impacted by high energy waves. Water could push further up the beach than normal. Property at Eastoke corner, near the nature reserve, and at Southwood Road may flood. Overtopping of splash walls along the beach front may flood gardens. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach may also be affected. Wednesday's tide at 00:44 04/02/2026 is forecast to be 12 cm lower (2.34 mAOD). 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 03 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
